an7.54:1: Then a certain bhikkhu approached the Blessed One, paid homage to him,sat down to one side, and said: "Bhante, why is it that doubt does not arise in the instructed noble disciple about the undeclared points?"[n.529] The undeclared points(abyākatavatthūni)are ten matters that the Buddha has not addressed: whether or not the world is eternal, whether the world is finite or infinite, whether the life-principle is the same as the body or different from the body, and the four alternatives concerning the after-death status of the Tathāgata.
an7.54:2: "With the cessation of views, bhikkhu, doubt does not arise in the instructed noble disciple about the undeclared points.
an7.54:3: "But the instructed noble disciple understands views, their origin, their cessation, and the way leading to their cessation. For him, that view ceases. He is freed from birth, from old age and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and anguish; he is freed from suffering, I say.
an7.54:4: (2) "‘The Tathāgata exists after death’: this is an involvement with craving … (3) … this isan involvement with perception … () … something conceived … (5) … a proliferation … (6) … an involvement with clinging … (7) … aground forremorse; ‘The Tathāgata does not exist after death’: this is aground forremorse; ‘The Tathāgata both exists and does not exist after death’: this is aground forremorse; ‘The Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist after death’: this is aground forremorse.
an7.54:5: "But the instructed noble disciple understands remorse, its origin, its cessation, and the way leading to its cessation. For him, that remorse ceases. He is freed from birth, from old age and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and anguish; he is freed from suffering, I say.
